t: So*p remember your Creator in the days of your youth: Before*pn the days of adversity come, and*ln the years approach when you will say, “I*ln have no delight in them”;
before*ln the sun and the light are darkened, and*ln the moon and the stars, and*ln the clouds return after the rain;
on*ln the day when the guardians of the house tremble, and*ln the strong men stoop, the*ln women who grind grain cease because they are few, and*ln the ones who watch through the windows see dimly,
the*ln doors at the street are shut while*ln the sound of the mill fades; when*ln one rises at the sound of a bird, and*ln all the daughters of song grow faint.

Also,*ln they are afraid of heights and dangers on the road; the*ln almond tree blossoms, the*ln grasshopper loses its spring, and*ln the caper berry has no effect; for*ln the mere mortal is headed to his eternal home, and*ln mourners will walk around in the street;
before*ln the silver cord is snapped, and*ln the gold bowl is broken, and*ln the jar is shattered at the spring, and*ln the wheel is broken into the well;
and*ln the dust returns to the earth as it once was, and*ln the spirit returns to God who gave it.
“Absolute*p futility,” says the Teacher. “Everything is futile.”
In*p addition to the Teacher being a wise man, he constantly taught the people knowledge; he weighed, explored, and arranged many proverbs.
The Teacher sought to find delightful sayings and write words of truth accurately.
The sayings of the wise are like cattle prods, and those from masters of collections are like firmly embedded nails. The sayings are given by one Shepherd.
But*p beyond these, my son, be warned: there is no end to the making of many books, and much study wearies the body.
When all has been heard, the conclusion of the matter is this: fear God and keep his commands, because this is for all humanity.
For God will bring every act to judgment, including every hidden thing, whether good or evil.
